questions.text: A 58-year-old male smoker was managed with primary PCI for STEMI 4 days ago. On the day of planned discharge he again develops central chest pain. Which of the following should be done in this patient to identify a reinfarction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Creatine Kinase-MB

Explanation:

In this scenario,CK-MB is the most useful marker for confirming reinfarction, as its levels normalize within 72 hours after an initial infarction.

Cardiac Biomarkers for Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI):

 

Cardiac Troponin T: (Option A)

  • Preferred biochemical markers due to their sensitivity and specificity.
  • Criteria for ACS: Requires rise and/or fall in biomarker values, with at least one value above the 99th percentile upper reference limit.
  • Troponin levels increase within 3-6 hours and remain elevated for 7-10 days after STEMI.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes at 8 am to the ER with chest pain that started last evening and has progressively worsened. She describes the pain as a burning sensation accompanied by a sour taste in her mouth, which began shortly after dinner. She has had similar experiences previously. This morning she passed a black stool. ECG and Echocardiography shows normal results. What is next investigation to be performed in this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B: Endoscopy

Explanation:

The patient is having chest pain due to reflux esophagitis. The first investigation to be done will be an Upper GI endoscopy which will show mucosal erythema and friability. Passage of black stool is a red flag, and endoscopy will help in determining whether it is bleeding due to mucosal erosions or peptic ulceration that has caused this presentation. Option A is the gold standard investigation and may not be available readily. Option C is a high-sensitivity troponin assay that would be done if presentation was of acute coronary syndrome. Option D is done for chronic stable angina.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with an acute onset of severe dyspnea and shock 5 days after receiving fibrinolysis for STEMI. On examination, an early systolic murmur is heard at the apex. Echocardiography reveals valvular dysfunction. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Papillary muscle rupture

Explanation:

The buzzword in the question is Echo report of valvular dysfunction implying, Papillary muscle rupture. This occurs after a STEMI due to ischemia of the papillary muscles, leading to acute mitral valve insufficiency. Auscultation finding of acute MR is early systolic murmur.

VSD will cause pansystolic murmur. LV aneurysm will cause clot formation and increased risk of stroke. Ventricular rupture will cause cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents 6 weeks after experiencing an ST-elevation myocardial infarction . He reports malaise, fever, and chest discomfort that worsens with deep breathing. On examination, a pericardial friction rub is heard. Laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and an elevated ESR. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aspirin

Explanation:

The scenario indicates Dressler syndrome due to fever, malaise, and pericardial effusion occurring 6 weeks post-myocardial infarction, reflecting a delayed inflammatory response. Elevated inflammatory markers confirm this autoimmune reaction to myocardial injury.Aspirin is the initial treatment as it reduces inflammation and relieves symptoms without risking complications associated with NSAIDs or glucocorticosteroids, which can impair healing after an MI.

Option D rescue PCI is done in case of failure of Fibrinolysis.


 

Dressler Syndrome

It is also known as post-myocardial infarction syndrome, it typically occurs 1 to 8 weeks after MI.

Symptoms: Patients may experience malaise, fever, pericardial discomfort, leukocytosis, elevated ESR, and pericardial effusion.

Pathology: Fibrinous pericarditis with polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) is often found at autopsy.

Cause: involves an immunopathologic process.

Treatment:

-Aspirin (650 mg every 4 hours) is the main treatment. (Option B)

-Glucocorticosteroids and NSAIDs should be avoided within 4 weeks of STEMI due to risks of impaired infarct healing, ventricular rupture. (Option A & C)

questions.text: A 72-year-old female with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with severe chest pain for 1 hour. Her ECG shows ST-elevation indicating a STEMI. She has a blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg and a history of active peptic ulcer disease. What is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Percutaneous coronary intervention

Explanation:

Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI): (Option D)

Restores perfusion effectively when performed on an emergency basis in the first few hours of a STEMI


 

Advantages Over Fibrinolysis:

  1. Can be performed in patients with contraindications to fibrinolytic therapy.
  2. Cardiogenic shock is present.
  3. Increased bleeding risk exists.



 

Absolute contraindications to fibrinolysis

 

History of cerebrovascular hemorrhage

Nonhemorrhagic stroke or cerebrovascular event in the past year.

Marked hypertension (>180/110 mmHg) at presentation.

Suspected aortic dissection.

Active internal bleeding (excluding menses)

Relative contraindications

 

Use of anticoagulants (INR >2).

Recent (<2 weeks) invasive procedure or prolonged (>10 min) CPR.

Bleeding diathesis

Pregnancy

Hemorrhagic ophthalmic conditions (e.g., hemorrhagic diabetic retinopathy)

Active peptic ulcer disease.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with chest pain lasting 45 minutes. His ECG shows STE in lead I, avL, V5, V6. Which of the following statements about his management is correct?

choices.text: Beta blockers should be avoided in all patients with STEMI.
First line drug for the management of STEMI is Streptokinase
LMWH provides more reliable anticoagulation than UFH.
Leading cause of death after 24 hours of hospitalization is cardiac rupture

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) LMWH provides more reliable anticoagulation than UFH.

Explanation:

Beta blockers reduce the size of the infarct by reducing oxygen consumption of the heart. So they are given to all patients unless some contraindication, like acute pulmonary edema or bradycardia, is present.

The leading cause of death after 24 hours of hospitalisation is Cardiogenic shock or pump failure. Cardiac rupture is rare.

The first drug given to patients with STEMI is aspirin chewable 325mg with Ticagrelor. So option B is wrong.

The main advantage of Low-Molecular-Weight Heparin is higher bioavailability, reliable anticoagulation without monitoring and a once-a-day regimen.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with central chest pain for the last 3 hours radiating to the left shoulder. On admission, blood pressure is 150/100 mmHg, and his oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?

choices.text: Administer morphine IV for pain relief
Administer nifedipine to relieve chest pain
Administer clopidogrel loading dose for platelet inhibition
Administer sublingual nitroglycerin (0.4 mg) to reduce myocardial oxygen demand

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Administer nifedipine to relieve chest pain

Explanation:

ECG shows ST elevations in leads II, III, aVF, V4-V6, indicating infero-lateral MI.

Calcium channel blockers, particularly short-acting dihydropyridines like nifedipine, will cause reflex tachycardia and increase myocardial oxygen demand. This can worsen the patient, and hence is the wrong statement

questions.text: Which of the following would provide the least accurate diagnosis of Myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Correct option: D) Radionuclide ventriculography

Explanation:

Radionuclide Ventriculography is used for the calculation of ejection fraction and not MI. Cardiac biomarkers are elevated due to necrosis of the myocardium. Echocardiography can show motion wall abnormality and identify ischemic-induced mechanical damage to heart valves and tissues. Coronary angiography will provide real-time evidence.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male presents with chest pain, and an ECG reveals the following changes



 

Based on these findings, which coronary artery is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anterior Interventricular Artery

Explanation:

ECG shows ST elevation in leads V1–V6, I, and aVL implying anterolateral MI. The blood vessel involved is proximal LAD also called anterior interventricular artery. Option A will cause lateral wall MI, option B will cause inferior wall MI and option D will cause posterior wall MI.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of coronary artery disease undergoes angiography, which reveals a thrombus in the right coronary artery (RCA). Based on this finding, which area of the heart is most likely to be affected by an infarct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inferior wall

Explanation:

In a patient with a thrombus in the right coronary artery, the area of the heart to be affected by an infarct is the inferior wall.

 

Coronary Artery Affected

Location of Infarct

Left Coronary Artery (LCA)

Extensive Anterior Wall MI

Left Circumflex Artery (LCX)

Lateral Wall MI

Left Anterior Descending (LAD)

Anterior Wall MI

Right Coronary Artery (RCA)

Inferior Wall MI

Posterior Descending Artery (PDA)

Posterior Wall MI


 

Coronary Circulation:

questions.text: Which of the following is correct placement for Lead II on the ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:D) Right arm (−) to Left leg (+)

Explanation:

In an ECG, the correct configuration for Lead II involves placing the positive electrode on the Left Leg (LL) and the negative electrode on the Right Arm (RA). This configuration allows the ECG to capture the electrical activity of the heart as it flows from the right atrium to the left ventricle.

12-Lead ECG System for Cardiac Monitoring

Limb Leads forming einthoven's Triangle

The concept of Einthoven's triangle is crucial for understanding lead placement in ECGs. It is an imaginary triangle formed by connecting the three limb electrodes (Right Arm, Left Arm, and Left Leg). The triangle represents the standard limb leads, which are as follows:

  • Lead I: Left Arm (+) to Right Arm (−)
  • Lead II: Left Leg (+) to Right Arm (−)
  • Lead III: Left Leg (+) to Left Arm (−)

 

Chest Leads:

  • V1: Placed in the 4th intercostal space (ICS) at the right parasternal line.
  • V2: Positioned in the 4th ICS at the left parasternal line.
  • V3: Located between V2 and V4.
  • V4: Found in the 5th ICS at the left midclavicular line.
  • V5: Set in the 5th ICS at the left anterior axillary line.
  • V6: Placed in the 5th ICS at the left midaxillary line.

 

Augmented Leads:

Augmented leads are called so because they provide a higher voltage output—about 1.5 times higher than limb leads thus enhancing the detection of electrical signals.

  • Lead aVL: Studies the left surface of the heart.
  • Lead aVR: Studies the right surface, reading inversely to routine leads.
  • Lead aVF: Acts like a camera positioned at the foot, scanning the diaphragm and right ventricle.

questions.text: A 56-year-old smoker male presented to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to his left shoulder, which was not relieved with rest. What is the earliest ECG change in Myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hyperacute T waves

Explanation:

Hyperacute T waves are often the earliest sign of myocardial infarction, characterized by broad, tall T waves. They appear before ST-segment elevation.

ST segment elevation shows a convexity in upward direction called tombstone pattern

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of severe chest pain that radiates to his left arm. This pain started about 60 minutes ago while he was having his breakfast. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. An ECG has been performed and cardiac biomarkers are significantly elevated.



What is the most likely cause of his presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Plaque rupture

Explanation:

The 12-lead ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, accompanied by reciprocal ST-segment depression in leads I and aVL, indicating an inferior wall ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction.The primary underlying cause of this STEMI is often the rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque, which results in thrombus formation and subsequent myocardial ischemia.

 

Coronary artery spasm (Prinzmetal’s angina) (Option A): This causes transient ST-segment elevation due to vasospasm but does not typically lead to the same pattern of ischemia or cardiac marker elevation seen in this patient.

 

Coronary artery embolism (Option B): Although a possible cause of myocardial infarction, it is much rarer compared to plaque rupture. Coronary emboli can result from conditions like atrial fibrillation or endocarditis but generally present differently.

 

Spontaneous coronary artery dissection (Option C): SCAD is a rare cause of myocardial infarction, seen mostly in younger women and often associated with pregnancy or connective tissue disorders. The presentation may differ from classic STEMI.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man underwent PCI with drug-eluting stents for double vessel disease yesterday. Today he develops chest pain with ECG showing ST-segment depression and cTn levels rising to five times the 99th percentile of the upper limit. What type of MI is seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Type 4

Explanation:

Post PCI myocardial infarction is classified as Type 4a MI. It has Troponin I values rising to 5x or more of normal.

 

Types of MI

Type 1 MI

Occurs due to Plaque rupture/ Ulceration/ coronary dissection with thrombus

Type 2 MI

Occurs due to supply demand mismatch

-Fixed coronary atherosclerosis

-Coronary spasm or Coronary embolism

-Coronary artery dissection without thrombus

-Sustained tachyarrhythmia, Severe bradyarrhythmia

-Severe anemia or hypotension

Type 3 MI

When sudden cardiac death occurs due to MI before biomarkers values could be drawn and sent to lab

Type 4a MI related to percutaneous coronary intervention

Requires a fivefold increase in cTn values if initial values are normal.

If initial cTn values are above the 99th percentile URL, a 20% rise is needed, with final values exceeding five times the 99th percentile.

Type 4b MI

This is associated with a stent thrombosis.

Type 4c MI

Associated with focal or diffuse restenosis after PCI

Type 5 MI related to coronary artery bypass grafting

Requires a tenfold increase in cTn values if initial values are normal.

If initial cTn values are above the 99th percentile URL, a 20% rise is needed, with final values exceeding ten times the 99th percentile.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about predisposition to atherosclerosis in these vessels?

choices.text: Popliteal arteries > Coronary arteries > Circle of Willis > Abdominal aorta
Coronary arteries > Abdominal aorta > Circle of Willis > Popliteal arteries
Abdominal aorta > Coronary arteries > Popliteal arteries > Circle of Willis
Coronary arteries > Circle of Willis > Abdominal aorta > Popliteal arteries

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Abdominal aorta > Coronary arteries > Popliteal arteries > Circle of Willis

Explanation:

Arteries Involved in Atherosclerosis in decreasing order of involvement ( mnemonic: ACP-Willis)

1. Abdominal Aorta: Formation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm in infrarenal abdominal aorta

2. Coronary Arteries

       - ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction

       - Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction / Unstable Angina

3. Popliteal Arteries: Atherosclerosis in these arteries leads to peripheral artery disease (PAD), causing intermittent claudication

4. Circle of Willis: Atherosclerotic plaques in the cerebral arteries can result in transient ischemic attacks (TIA) or strokes.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with chest pain at rest for the past 4 hours. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. ECG shows ST-segment depression in lead II, III, aVF and his cardiac troponin levels are elevated. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Aspirin and Ticagrelor

Explanation:

The patient is having NSTE - inferior wall MI. Initial treatment in both types of MI is aspirin with Ticagrelor as platelet aggregation is the initial step in thrombus formation.

CABG is done in triple vessel disease and will be scheduled in this patient at a later date based on an Angiography report. Thrombolysis is Contraindicated in NSTEMI. Statins and ACEi are used but are not the initial treatment.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman with T2DM presents to ER with chest discomfort at rest radiationg to jaw and nausea for past 2 hours. ECG shows T wave inversion and ST depression in lead II, III, aVF. Trop I value is greater than 99th centile of upper reference limit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Non-ST elevation MI

Explanation:

The scenario here points to NSTEMI  which is diagnosed by raised serum troponin levels, ECG changes of T-wave inversion, and clinical symptoms of chest pain. Unstable angina is ruled out as it has normal biomarkers. 

Stable angina (Option A) is a type of ischemic heart disease that occurs when the heart muscle does not receive adequate oxygen due to reduced blood flow through the coronary arteries, especially during physical exertion or emotional stress and presents with chest pain that lasts 2-10 minutes and is relieved on rest.

ST-Elevation MI (Option D) is caused by prolonged obstruction of blood supply to a part of the heart muscle, leading to tissue damage or necrosis, and has significant ST elevation in the ECG.

questions.text:
Check out this ECG finding and select the condition(s) that can present with this change? 




	Hyperkalemia
	Variant Angina
	Digoxin (Therapeutic doses)
	Left Ventricular Hypertrophy (LVH)
	Chronic Stable Angina
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1 and 2 

Explanation:

Conditions for ST elevation- Due to systolic current injury and ST depression

ST Elevation

ST Depression
  • Acute Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
  • Prinzmetal Angina (Option 2)
  • Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB)
  • Brugada syndrome
  • Pericarditis ( acute) 
  • Benign early repolarization
  • Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy
  • Aortic Dissection
  • Hyperkalemia (Option 1)
  • Non-ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI)
  • Digoxin (Therapeutic doses) (Option 3 ruled out)
  • Chronic Stable Angina (Option 5 ruled out)
  • Subendocardial ischemia (LV hypertrophy) 
  • Hypokalemia

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the ER with early morning episode of chest pain lasting 15 minutes which is relieved by sublingual nitroglycerin. She has had similiar episodes in past and her husband says that metoprolol was started which worsend her chest pain episodes so they stopped the medication. Past medical history is significant for Raynaud phenomenon. ECG  is given below. There is no elevation of cardiac markers on serial evaluation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Prinzmetal angina

Explanation:

Based on the given scenario, the diagnosis is consistent with Prinzmetal angina, which is characterized by episodes of chest pain at rest, often relieved by nitroglycerin, and associated with transient ST-segment elevations on ECG. It is caused by coronary artery spasm rather than obstructive coronary artery disease, and cardiac markers remain normal during these episodes. 

Stable angina (Option A): This type of angina is typically triggered by physical exertion or emotional stress and is characterized by predictable episodes of chest pain. It does not usually occur at rest and does not show transient ST-segment elevations during rest episodes.

Unstable angina (Option B): This condition involves chest pain that occurs at rest, is more severe, and may last longer than stable angina.

Myocardial infarction (Option D): MI typically presents with prolonged chest pain, elevated cardiac markers, and more significant ECG changes such as ST-segment elevation or depression that do not resolve with nitroglycerin.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to ER central chest pain at rest and shortness of breath for last one hour. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Troponin I is elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient's condition?

choices.text: IV atropine followed by temporary pacing

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chewable Aspirin and Atorvastatin

Explanation:

Patient is having elevated cardiomarker with ECG showing ST elevation in V2-V4. Diagnosis is STEMI and Chweable aspirin to inhibit clot formation and atorvastatin to stabilize atherosclerotic plaque must be done immediately. The patient will subsequently scheduled for PCI. Option D is ruled as Heart rate is 75 bpm. Option C Eptifibatide is used in NSTEMI/UA before PCI.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is known case of chronic stable angina and has undergone PCI with stenting last year. Today morning she presents to ER with a 60-minute episode of chest discomfort that occurred while she was watching television. She describes the pain as a tightness in his chest, radiating to her left arm. She has a history of T2DM and has deranged lipid profile. An ECG reveals inverted T-waves. Which of the following is best next step in managment of this patient?

choices.text: Send to Cath lab for PCI

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cardiac biomarkers 

Explanation:

The patient is known case of chronic stable angina and has already undergone a revascularization procedure. Due to T2DM and deranged lipids , atherosclerosis process is still ongoing and has today caused her to develop Acute coronarry syndrome. Since ECG shows T wave inversion she is either is having unstable angina or NSTEMI. To differentiate between the two, Cardiac biomarkers must be done initially She may require PCI later but first diagnosis needs to be established.

questions.text: What is the revascularization procedure of choice for two different cases, Patient A with triple vessel disease and Patient B with left anterior descending artery blockage with EF < 40%?

choices.text: A: CABG; B: PCI with stenting
CABG for both A and B
A: PCI with stenting; B: CABG
A: PCI with Bare metal stenting ; B: PCI with drug eluting stenting

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CABG for both

Explanation:

CABG is standard of care for Multivessel disease and Left coronary artery involvement with low EF 

Condition

Preferred Treatment
  • Single or two-vessel disease (non-proximal LAD, non-left main)
  • High surgical risk (comorbidities)
  • Contraindication to surgery
  • Elderly patients (>80 years or frailty)

PCI (Percutaneous Coronary Intervention)
  • Multivessel disease
  • Proximal LAD involvement with low EF ( < 40%) 
  • Left main coronary artery involvement
  • In-stent restenosis (with DES in major arteries)

CABG (Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with chronic stable angina presents with chest pain during routine activities. His current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, isosorbide mononitrate and atorvastatin, but his symptoms persist. Coronary angiography reveals 90% stenosis of the right coronary artery. and 70% in LCX.  What is the most appropriate intervention?

choices.text: Increase the dose of Long acting nitrates
Refer for coronary artery bypass grafting

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) PCI with stenting 

Explanation:

The patient has significant stenosis in two vessels ( double vessel disease ) and persistent anginal symptoms despite optimal medical therapy. PCI with a drug-eluting stent is the most appropriate intervention in this scenario, as it restores blood flow and relieves symptoms. If patient had Triple vessel disease or had LAD stenosis with low ejection fraction less than 40% then , CABG would be done .

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of CAD presents with recurrent syncope. Considering his intermediate to high risk for CAD, which imaging modality would be most appropriate for further evaluation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Myocardial Perfusion Imaging 
 

Explanation:

Myocardial perfusion imaging is ideal for evaluating ischemia in patients with intermediate to high CAD risk, like this patient with a history of CAD and syncope. Thallium-201 imaging effectively detects areas of reduced blood flow, helping identify underlying ischemic disease. It's preferred when structural heart disease has been ruled out, as in this case, where echocardiography showed no abnormalities.

Since the patient has had syncopal episodes , it would be too risky a test as pateint can fall and sustain a fatal injury 

Multigated Acquisition (MUGA) Scanning (Option C ruled out)

Indications:

  • Cardiac Function in Chemotherapy: Evaluates cardiac function in patients receiving potentially cardiotoxic chemotherapy.
  • Anatomical Assessment: Assesses the orientation of the heart and great vessels in the chest.
  • Ischemic Disease Detection: Identifies undiagnosed ischemic disease in patients with hypodynamic wall motion without prior myocardial infarction.
  • Heart Failure Evaluation: Determines systolic or diastolic dysfunction in undiagnosed congestive heart failure by analyzing ventricular filling and contraction.
  • Valvular Function and COPD: Evaluates valve motion and associated ventricular function, cardiac function in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and checks for intracardiac shunts

questions.text: A 60-year-old smoker male presents with chest pain on climbing stairs. He is started on low dose aspirin, statins and metoprolol by his GP. His symptoms have worsened despite medical therapy.What is the next best step in diagnosing the extent of his coronary artery disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D: CCTA 

For diagnosis of extent of coronary artery involvement CCTA or invasive coronary angiography needs to be done. Coronary CT angiography is a non invasive method and would be acceptable to most patients intially. If this patient had developed ACS and needed intervention then invasive coronary angiography would be required.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male undergoes a treadmill ECG stress test and develops 2 mm of horizontal ST-segment depression after 12 minutes of exercise. He reports non-limiting chest pain (angina index = 1). What is his Duke Treadmill Score (DTS) and his risk category?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) DTS = -2; Intermediate risk.

Explanation:

Duke Treadmill Score (DTS) is calculated using the formula:

DTS = Exercise time (in minutes) − (5× ST-segment deviation (in mm)) − (4 × angina index)

  • The patient exercised for 12 minutes.
  • There was 2 mm of horizontal ST-segment depression, so multiply by 5. 5×2=10
  • The patient reported non-limiting chest pain, so the angina index = 1 (non-limiting angina). 4×1=4
  • Therefore, the DTS calculation: DTS = 12 −10 − 4= −2DTS
  • This places the patient in the intermediate-risk category.

 

Risk Interpretation:

Risk

DTS

Interpretation

Low Risk

≥ 5

No need for further coronary angiography.

Intermediate Risk (Option C)

+4 to –10

May need further tests, such as myocardial perfusion scanning or coronary angiography.

High Risk

< –10

Requires further investigation with coronary angiography.

questions.text: An elderly male with a history of cigarette smoking and hypertension develops chest pain after an evening walk. The pain is relieved after lying down for a few minutes. A treadmill stress test reveals ST-segment depression. What is the most likely cause attributed to this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Chronic Stable Angina

Explanation:

Chronic stable angina occurs due to myocardial ischemia during exertion, especially in patients with risk factors such as smoking and hypertension. It is characterized by chest pain that is relieved by rest.

ST-segment depression on the treadmill test suggests ischemia without infarction, consistent with stable angina.

 

Chronic Stable Angina (Reversible Ischemia)

Chronic stable angina, or exertional angina, is a type of ischemic heart disease that occurs when the heart muscle does not receive adequate oxygen due to reduced blood flow through the coronary arteries, especially during physical exertion or emotional stress.

Incidence:
M/c in males and postmenopausal females, particularly in individuals over the age of 60.

Risk Factors:

  • Smoking
  • Hypertension
  • Diabetes
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Family history of coronary artery disease

 

Clinical Features:

Chest Pain (Angina Pectoris): The primary symptom is chest discomfort or pain, often described as a squeezing, tightness, or pressure sensation.

Triggers: Commonly triggered by physical activity or emotional stress, which increase the heart's oxygen demand, leading to angina.

Duration: Usually lasts 5 to 10 minutes.

Relief: The pain typically resolves with rest or the use of sublingual nitroglycerin within a few minutes.

 

ECG Findings:

  • Asymptomatic Phase: The ECG is usually normal during rest or when the patient is not experiencing chest pain.
  • Symptomatic Phase (During Angina): The hallmark ECG finding is ST-segment depression, indicating subendocardial ischemia due to insufficient blood flow to the inner layer of the heart muscle.

 

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Option A): This condition usually presents with exertional dyspnea, syncope, or palpitations rather than chest pain. While it may cause ischemia, it is not typically associated with ST-segment depression on a treadmill test.

 

Prinzmetal Angina (Option B): This type of angina is caused by coronary artery spasm and typically occurs at rest, often during nighttime or early morning. It can be associated with transient ST-segment elevation rather than depression.

 

Non-ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI) (Option C): While NSTEMI can present with ST-segment depression, the chest pain is more persistent and not typically relieved by rest. Additionally, NSTEMI often shows elevated cardiac biomarkers, indicating myocardial injury.

questions.text:
Arrange the following structures of an atherosclerotic plaque from the innermost to the outermost layer:


	Fibrous cap
	Necrotic core
	Foam cell layer
	Media

choices.text: Fibrous cap → Foam cell layer→ Necrotic core → Media
Necrotic core → Media → Foam cell layer → Fibrous cap
Foam cell layer → Fibrous cap → Media→ Necrotic core
Foam cell layer → Necrotic core → Fibrous cap → Media

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fibrous cap → Foam cell layer→ Necrotic core → Media

Explanation:

 

Structure of Atheromatous Plaque

Endothelium

The innermost arterial lining that regulates blood flow, prevents clot formation, and controls inflammation. Damage to the endothelium due to factors like hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking initiates plaque formation.

Fibrous Cap

Smooth muscle cells from the media migrate to the intima and secrete collagen, forming a protective fibrous cap over the lipid core. Cap stability determines plaque vulnerability.

Foamy Cell Layer

Lipoproteins like LDL accumulate in the subendothelial space after endothelial injury. Macrophages engulf oxidized LDL, becoming foam cells, forming lipid-rich fatty streaks.

Necrotic Core

Foam cells die, releasing lipids and forming a necrotic core, consisting of dead cells and cholesterol crystals. A large necrotic core increases plaque instability.

Media

The smooth muscle-rich middle arterial layer thins and weakens during plaque development as muscle cells move to form the fibrous cap.

 

Sequence of Atherosclerosis Development

Endothelial Injury
Damage to the arterial inner lining, often due to hypertension, smoking, diabetes, or highcholesterol.

↓

Lipid Accumulation
Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) infiltrates the damaged endothelium and accumulates in the arterial wall.

↓

Inflammation
Immune cells (macrophages) engulf lipids, forming foam cells and triggering inflammation.

↓

Plaque Formation
Foam cells and lipids build up, creating a plaque with a necrotic core and a fibrous cap, narrowing the artery.

↓

Plaque Rupture
Rupture of the fibrous cap can cause thrombosis, leading to artery obstruction and ischemic events like heart attack or stroke.
